awd_titl_txt: Conference: INCLUDES: Culturewise Pathways to Indigenous STEM Education
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF INCLUDES Program, this project aims to address the significant and persistent lack of integration of local ecological knowledge with western STEM education. Neglecting Indigenous perspectives limits opportunities for Indigenous learners to pursue STEM courses and careers and creates broadening participation challenges in STEM education. To address this challenge, the project will convene a group of Indigenous academic, community, and education leaders. Over three conference phases, this group will share authentic, culturally specific examples of what works and does not work in STEM education for Indigenous learners. These discussions will help establish a vision for inclusive Indigenous education. The project will produce a compendium of learnings for dissemination in-person, in print, and online. The evaluation may reveal how conference participants and educators approach and deliver culturally responsive STEM education.    

The goal of the project is to gather exemplary community-driven STEM education designed for Indigenous students. During Phase I, conference participants will facilitate knowledge sharing and identify innovative strategies. In Phase II, participants will work in small groups using learnings to develop recommendations and action plans for broadening Indigenous participation in STEM. The project team hypothesizes that the Phase III dissemination of conference Proceedings can improve educator capacities to envision and enact culturally appropriate STEM instruction. In addition, these resources can contribute to systemic improvements in STEM education that foster inclusivity and broaden participation among Indigenous learners. Through these efforts, the project aims to bridge the gap between Indigenous knowledge and western STEM literacy, ultimately paving the way for increased Indigenous representation and success in STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Culturewise Pathways to Indigenous Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Educationconference invited an intergenerational network of 30 Indigenous community members including teachers, teacher educators, faculty, industry professionals, healthcare workers, and elders/knowledge keepers to deliberate Indigenous participation in STEM. This 3-day virtual conference is of great significance built on the trust and respect that has developed over decades of being deeply connected with a large, integrated network of national and international Indigenous scholars and leaders. 

The conference spanned three full days. At the start of each day, after the introduction, a leading Indigenous scholar presented a keynote in their area of expertise. Each scholar shared current knowledge related to their area of expertise. The first keynote emphasized the resurgence of Indigenous science as a vital means to address ecological challenges, advocating for the integration of traditional knowledge into modern education and environmental practices to inspire Indigenous communities. The Day 2 keynote highlighted the importance of reconnecting Indigenous communities with their lands through immersive educational practices by advocating for evidence-based models and collaborative environments to foster cultural revitalization and systemic change. The final keynote addressed embedding Indigenous knowledge into education to create a more inclusive curriculum that emphasizes the human aspect of science and the need for community involvement to effectively implement educational reforms. The inspiring keynotes energized and mentally prepared the participants for rich, insightful discussions. Following each keynote address, participants convened in small groups, rotating through three focus areas: 1) shared responsibilities in public education among Tribal leaders, communities and families; 2) connecting classrooms to communities for optimal community-based contribution; and 3) community collaboration to enhance balanced, culturally and linguistically relevant education, all of which contributed to our discussions of broadening participation in STEM. 

Conference participants shared successful strategies to boost STEM participation among Indigenous students by involving local communities. This involves partnerships with tribal education offices, collaboration with Indigenous-led organizations, and community engagement to ensure educational relevance. For example, utilizing affordable technologies like phone cameras for virtual field experiences can connect students with their local environment and heritage. Integrating cultural, place-based, and community-led approaches driven by local knowledge and values is another way to boost STEM participation. Through the multiday discussions, the conference identified next steps to broaden STEM participation among Indigenous students. Collaborative proposals can be developed to infuse culturally appropriate instruction in STEM by enhancing teacher preparation programs that promote professional growth aligned with Indigenous perspectives. This kind of collaboration can bolster on-going professional growth of teachers, administrators, and evaluators. As an outcome of the conference, collaborative proposals focused on next steps are being developed.

 

Written reports included an evaluation summary of the themes and questions that emerged. The themes are significant because they reflect modernized Indigenous education within a more global urban center that maintains strong ties to culture and place. Participants filled the conference with ideas of how to use what they learned to shape their work, for example, in culture camps. Participants felt energized to continue to work together to engage in research projects that contribute to our understanding of how multicultural Indigeneity and the mobility of communities’ influence STEM engagement. 

The conference organized opportunities for participants to share, network, and begin planning next steps to create pathways that provide Indigenous youth greater access to participate in conversations and key learnings. This conference and the resulting resources will have broad impact by deepening understanding of the opportunities and challenges to delivering exemplary Native education through tribal sovereignty and self-determination, to increase Indigenous participation in STEM.
